conclusion: Determine the change in the range of angles of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole after embedding the glass brick.
Use Snell's Law and basic trigonometry to find the solution.
Circular light hole with diameter 40 cm and thickness 20√3 cm; glass brick with refractive index √3 is embedded.
Find the change in the range of angles of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the hole.
Maximum angle θ_max before embedding is determined by geometry: tan(θ_max) = 1/√3, so θ_max = 30°.
Light refracts according to Snell's Law: n_1 sin(i) = n_2 sin(r).
For maximum angle i = 30°, sin(r) = 1/(2√3), so r = sin^(-1)(1/(2√3)).
Maximum angle θ_max inside the glass is determined by tan(θ_max, glass) = 1/√3, so θ_max, glass = 30°.
Range of angles inside the glass is increased because refracted angle r is smaller than incident angle i.
Increase in range of angles is 60° - 30° = 30°.
The range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole is increased by 30° compared with that before embedding the glass brick.
